head.title: At Least 119 Dead as Heavy Rains Set Off Floods in South Africa

hedline.hl1: At Least 119 Dead as Heavy Rains Set Off Floods in South Africa

block.p: At least 119 people died and many more were missing in floods caused by heavy rains in South Africa's KwaZulu-Natal Province, the police said today.
Police divers, rescue teams, residents and helicopters were pulling out bodies from the Umsunduze River and its tributary, the Slangspruit, which overflowed Monday night.
At least 119 people died and many more were missing in floods caused by heavy rains in South Africa's KwaZulu-Natal Province, the police said today.
Police divers, rescue teams, residents and helicopters were pulling out bodies from the Umsunduze River and its tributary, the Slangspruit, which overflowed Monday night.
A police spokesman, Henry Budrum, said that 119 bodies had been recovered so far.
The victims all lived in Imbali, near Edendale, a black township outside Pietermaritzburg.
"We are expecting to find many more overnight and tomorrow," Mr. Budrum said.
The police and residents said that the water level had dropped and that the townships were no longer in danger unless heavy rain resumes.
Residents scoured the riverbanks searching for relatives while a police helicopter airlifted body bags carrying victims.
An Imbali resident, Enock Nhlangulela, said he had lost nine relatives in the floods.
"I was lucky because I went to visit friends when the heavy rains came," he said.
"When I returned I found everyone and everything inside the house had been washed away."
A provincial legislator, Sifiso Nkabinde, said the regional government has declared Imbali township a disaster area.
For many years Edendale and Imbali were the scene of bitter fighting between supporters of President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress and Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi's Inkatha Freedom Party.

Political violence has eased since elections in April last year ended white-minority rule. But on Monday at least 14 people were killed in a raid by Inkatha supporters on backers of the Congress in the Shobashobane settlement in the area.
